Author: icky
Content:
DH-3.5: Disagreeing with the author's Disagreement Hierarchy.

This category is particularly troublesome, as even when both parties agree, in principle, to disagree, they may still disagree on how to disagree.

One particular nuisance is the disagreer who seeks to impose a disagreement meta-hierarchy on the problem of agreeing on a disagreement hierarchy. That way is turtles, all the way down.

Author: joshua_steffan
Content: "You can't call me an idiot", cried the idiot. That's Ad Hominem, y'know!

Author: wehriam
Content: Right behind you on this one. After reading the article I was terrified that YC.News would line up behind PG - how refreshing to see that the community is more than happy to dissent. I don't agree, but I really respect the forum which he was instrumental in creating.

Author: gensym
Content:
There's a form of disagreement that I don't think fits into the hierarchy - where, rather than arguing that the author is incorrect, you argue that the author should not be saying that at all. This relates to the ideas in http://www.paulgraham.com/say.html.

It can be the simple "Hey! I put my braces on the next line, and I take offense at that!", to the "Arguing that all left-handed programmers write unmaintainable code is irresponsible because ...".

It's like responding to tone, but you are responding to what is being argued, rather than how it's written. It might not really be a disagreement since you aren't saying that the author is incorrect, but neither is "u r a fag!!!!!!!!!!".

Author: trekker7
Content: Amazing... does anybody have any more information about this? Is this a trick where an elephant gets trained for many years to draw images, and gets used to the actions of moving the paintbrush across a canvas in a particular way (still an awesome feat)? Or do elephants naturally have drawing skills? Is there evidence that wild elephants draw things on cave walls, etc. by scratching on them with rocks or something?

Author: anescient
Content: Or set your HDD as the only boot device and set a BIOS password.

Author: wheels
Content: All news sites are biased, moreso if they are community maintained.  It's not devious; it's just sociology.  Communities tend to reinforce values that they agree with or validate what they are doing, especially if it's risky.  I think the sollution is to just factor that into your reading.

Author: trekker7
Content: I thought this was one of PG's best essays. A lot of the other ones are motivational or thought-provoking, but in terms of usefulness and clear thinking, this was it.

Author: dcurtis
Content: Thank you for that. A full six minutes of mindless humor.
